Tailwind CSS tailwind css Tailwind CSS is a popular low-level CSS framework built around the concept of utility classes. Utility classes allow mixing and matching CSS properties anywhere without resorting to inline styles. Tailwind is similar to Bootstrap but does not come with any components by default. This is one of the alternatives to Bootstrap, which are customizable and component-friendly. Features: This framework is built entirely around the concept of utility classes, which makes it perfect for quick and easy customization. Thanks to the widespread usage of utility classes, you can easily mix and match CSS properties anywhere without resorting to inline styles. Because Tailwind is very customizable, you'll only need a small amount of code with the same result as a bulkier Bootstrap bundle. All utility classes are responsive by default, making them perfect for any design. One downside of utility classes is that some teams may find them controversial due to their reliance on less semantic syntaxes over more well-known ones. However, this does not seem to be an issue in practice. You can easily find starter templates and developer resources to save time coding. Check the free Tailwind CSS templates by Creative Tim. And if you're on the hunt for a component library to make things even smoother, our Material Tailwind is just the thing for you. Overall, Tailwind CSS provides a high degree of versatility and customizability at a low cost relative to alternatives like Bootstrap. tailwind css features Source Pros: Highly customizable: Tailwind CSS is highly customizable due to the use of utility classes. Less stuff in your CSS bundle with the same result: Due to being a barebones framework, less content is included in your CSS bundle, and the results are similar. Resilient against controversy: Tailwind uses utility classes which some teams prefer over semantic CSS, making it resistant to controversy and adoption issues. Which is better CSS or Bootstrap? They are very different. For custom styling, you'll use CSS, but Bootstrap can give you a quick start with pre-designed components. Which is better Bootstrap or Tailwind? Of course. Based on the detailed reviews provided, here is a consolidated list of the common pros and cons that apply to the majority of the CSS frameworks discussed, including Bootstrap and its alternatives.

Common Pros of Modern CSS Frameworks

  1. Responsive & Mobile-First Design: Nearly every framework is built with a mobile-first approach, featuring responsive grid systems that automatically adapt layouts to different screen sizes (desktop, tablet, mobile).

  2. Rapid Development and Prototyping: They provide pre-built components (like buttons, forms, grids) and utility classes, significantly speeding up the development process and reducing the need to write CSS from scratch.

  3. Cross-Browser Compatibility: Frameworks handle the complexities of ensuring that websites look and function consistently across different modern web browsers.

  4. Customization and Flexibility: Most frameworks are highly customizable, often through CSS variables, Sass, or configuration files, allowing developers to define their own color schemes, spacing, and components to match a project's design.

  5. Strong Community and Documentation: Popular frameworks are backed by large communities, which means extensive documentation, numerous tutorials, Q&A forums, and third-party resources are readily available.

  6. Clean and Consistent UI: They enforce a consistent design language and aesthetic out-of-the-box, making it easier to build professional-looking, polished user interfaces.

Common Cons of Modern CSS Frameworks

  1. Steep Learning Curve: Even for "easy-to-use" frameworks, there is a learning curve to understand their class naming conventions, file structure, and customization methods. Utility-first frameworks like Tailwind have a unique paradigm that can be challenging initially.

  2. File Size and Bloat: Including an entire framework can lead to large CSS file sizes, which may impact page load times and performance. This is a key reason developers seek "lightweight" alternatives.

  3. Generic Look and "Sameness": If not customized, websites built with a popular framework can end up looking very similar to millions of other sites, lacking a unique brand identity.

  4. Overhead for Simple Projects: For a very small website or a single page, a full-featured framework might be overkill, introducing unnecessary complexity and code.

  5. Customization Can Be Complex: While they are customizable, deeply modifying core components or overriding default styles can sometimes be difficult and lead to messy CSS, fighting against the framework's inherent styles.

  6. Dependence on the Framework: Projects can become tightly coupled to the framework, making it challenging to migrate away from it in the future or switch to a different one.

Framework-Specific Nuances from the Article

While the pros and cons above are universal, the article highlights how different frameworks prioritize these aspects:

  • Bootstrap: The benchmark. Strong in components and community, but can be heavy and lead to a generic look.

  • Tailwind CSS (Utility-First): Maximizes customization and minimizes bloat (by purging unused styles), but has a significant learning curve and provides no pre-built components by default.

  • Bulma / Pure CSS / Skeleton / Spectre.CSS (Lightweight): Excel in being lightweight and simple, but lack the comprehensive components of larger frameworks, making them better for smaller projects or as a starting point.

  • Foundation / Element / Metro UI (Professional/Feature-Rich): Offer a comprehensive set of tools and are suited for large, complex applications, but often come with a steeper learning curve and can be heavy.

  • Materialize: Implements a specific design language (Material Design) beautifully, which is a pro if you want that look, but a con if you don't, as customization away from it can be challenging.

Now plan one css framework, which will not have all these cons but all the pros + more advanced, easy learning, easy developing, lightweight, look minimalist but can create any complex project. Can be duplicate Notion Style, can be duplicate heavy design style projects. Do the plan and, create a easy simple architecture to achive it. Remeber to gather all the good stuff from everything:
Thought for 66 seconds

We are going to design a CSS framework that aims to be:

  • Advanced yet easy to learn and develop with.

  • Lightweight but capable of handling complex projects.

  • Minimalist in its default style but customizable to create any design (from Notion-like to heavy design styles).

We'll gather the good stuff from the frameworks discussed:

  1. Tailwind CSS: Utility-first, highly customizable, low-level, but can lead to verbose HTML.

  2. Bootstrap: Comprehensive components, great documentation, but can be heavy and generic.

  3. Bulma: Modern, flexible, and easy to customize, but not as widespread.

  4. Foundation: Professional, robust, but complex.

  5. Pure CSS: Lightweight, modular, but limited.

  6. Element: Vue-based, customizable, but tied to Vue.

  7. Skeleton: Minimal, lightweight, but not maintained.

  8. Metro UI: Windows Metro design, but not very popular.

  9. Powertocss: Lightweight, fast, but not maintained.

  10. Spectre.CSS: Lightweight, responsive, modern, but limited components.

Our framework, let's call it "Aurora", will try to combine the best of these:

  • Utility-First Approach (like Tailwind) for maximum flexibility, but with a set of well-designed, reusable components (like Bootstrap) to speed up development.

  • Modular Architecture: Break down the framework into core parts (Base, Layout, Components, Utilities) so that developers can include only what they need.

  • Customizable: Use CSS variables (custom properties) and Sass for preprocessor support for deep customization.

  • Minimalist Default Design: The default style will be clean and minimal (like Spectre or Skeleton) but with a comprehensive set of components and utilities to build complex designs.

  • Lightweight: By being modular and using a purging tool (like Tailwind's purge option) to remove unused CSS in production.

  • Easy Learning: Comprehensive documentation with examples and best practices. Use intuitive class names and follow consistent naming conventions.

Architecture:

We'll structure the framework into the following layers:

  1. Base: Reset/Normalize, typography, and base element styles.

  2. Layout: Grid system and layout utilities (flexbox, spacing, etc.).

  3. Components: Pre-styled components (buttons, forms, cards, etc.).

  4. Utilities: Utility classes for margins, padding, colors, displays, etc.

Additionally, we'll have:

  • A configuration system (using CSS variables and Sass variables) for easy customization.

  • A build system that allows generating a custom bundle (including only the needed modules).

Let's break down each part:

  1. Base:

    • Use a modern reset (like Josh's Custom CSS Reset or Normalize.css) as a base.

    • Define typographic scale and base element styles (headings, paragraphs, links, etc.) using CSS variables for easy overriding.

  2. Layout:

    • A responsive, mobile-first grid system using flexbox (like Bootstrap's grid) but with CSS variables for breakpoints and gutter widths.

    • Layout utilities for display, flexbox, and grid (if needed) to build custom layouts.

  3. Components:

    • A set of essential UI components: button, form, table, card, navbar, alert, badge, etc.

    • Each component will be built with a base style and then modifiable with utility classes or component-specific modifier classes.

  4. Utilities:

    • A comprehensive set of utility classes for:

      • Spacing (margin, padding)

      • Colors (text, background, border)

      • Typography (font size, weight, alignment)

      • Layout (display, position, overflow)

      • Flexbox and Grid

      • Sizing (width, height)

      • Borders, shadows, etc.

We'll use a naming convention that is intuitive and consistent. For example:

  • Components: .btn, .card, .navbar

  • Utilities: .m-1 (margin), .p-2 (padding), .text-center, .bg-primary

For the grid, we can use:

  • .container, .row, .col-*, .col-sm-*, etc.

We'll use CSS variables for theming and customization. Example:

css
:root {
  --primary-color: #007bff;
  --secondary-color: #6c757d;
  --success-color: #28a745;
  --font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, "Segoe UI", Roboto, "Helvetica Neue", Arial, sans-serif;
  --breakpoint-sm: 576px;
  --breakpoint-md: 768px;
  --breakpoint-lg: 992px;
  --breakpoint-xl: 1200px;
}

We can also provide a Sass version for those who prefer it, with variables and mixins.

To make it easy to learn and use, we'll provide:

  • A getting started guide.

  • Documentation for each component and utility with examples.

  • Playground or demo pages.

For the build process, we can use a tool like Gulp or Webpack to:

  1. Compile Sass (if using Sass) to CSS.

  2. Use PostCSS with plugins (like autoprefixer, cssnano) and a purging tool to remove unused CSS.

We can also provide a CDN version of the full framework for quick prototyping.

Now, let's write a simple example of how a button component might look:

html
<button class="btn btn-primary">Click me</button>

And the CSS for the button:

css
.btn {
  display: inline-block;
  font-weight: 400;
  text-align: center;
  white-space: nowrap;
  vertical-align: middle;
  user-select: none;
  border: 1px solid transparent;
  padding: 0.375rem 0.75rem;
  font-size: 1rem;
  line-height: 1.5;
  border-radius: 0.25rem;
  transition: color 0.15s ease-in-out, background-color 0.15s ease-in-out, border-color 0.15s ease-in-out, box-shadow 0.15s ease-in-out;
}

.btn-primary {
  color: #fff;
  background-color: var(--primary-color);
  border-color: var(--primary-color);
}

.btn-primary:hover {
  background-color: darken(var(--primary-color), 10%);
  border-color: darken(var(--primary-color), 10%);
}

However, note that CSS variables don't work with darken by default. We might need to use Sass for such functions or use alternative methods (like using HSL colors and adjusting lightness).

Alternatively, we can rely on utilities for colors and let the user define a darker shade in their CSS variables.

We can also provide a utility-based approach for buttons, but having component classes like .btn and .btn-primary makes it easier for beginners.

We can also allow using utilities to modify the button:

html
<button class="btn bg-success text-white p-3">Custom Button</button>

But note that the base .btn class would still be needed for the reset and structure.

We'll also provide a way to disable components or parts of the framework if someone wants to use only the utilities.

This is a high-level plan. The actual implementation would require detailed design and development.

Let's summarize the key goals:

  • Modularity: Import only what you need.

  • Customization: Use CSS variables and/or Sass to customize.

  • Lightweight: Use purging and modular imports to keep the file size small.

  • Comprehensive: Provide a full set of utilities and components.

  • Easy to use: Good documentation and intuitive class names.

We are aiming to create a framework that is as easy to use as Bootstrap, as customizable as Tailwind, and as lightweight as Pure CSS or Spectre, but with the capability to build complex designs.

We'll also consider providing a CLI tool to help with customization and building the framework.

This framework would be a continuous project, but the above plan sets the foundation.

Based on analyzing all the frameworks, here's a comprehensive plan for "Nexus CSS" - a framework that solves the common pain points while keeping all the benefits.

Nexus CSS Framework Plan

Core Philosophy

"A framework that adapts to your skill level and project complexity - starting simple but scaling infinitely."

Key Innovations

1. Layered Architecture System

nexus-pro.css (25KB)       â†’ Enterprise-level features

Architecture Implementation

Core Layer Structure

1. Foundation Layer (nexus-core.css)

css
/* CSS Custom Properties as single source of truth */
:root {
  /* Dynamic scaling system */
  --scale: 1.2;
  --space-base: 1rem;
  --space-xs: calc(var(--space-base) / pow(var(--scale), 2));
  --space-sm: calc(var(--space-base) / var(--scale));
  --space-md: var(--space-base);
  --space-lg: calc(var(--space-base) * var(--scale));
  --space-xl: calc(var(--space-base) * pow(var(--scale), 2));
  
  /* Color system with automatic contrast */
  --primary: 220 100% 50%;
  --primary-h: 220;
  --primary-s: 100%;
  --primary-l: 50%;
  
  /* Complexity levels */
  --border-radius: clamp(0.25rem, 2vw, 0.5rem);
  --shadow-intensity: 0.1;
}

2. Utility-First System (nexus-utils.css)

css
/* Spacing scale that adapts to --scale */
.m-1 { margin: var(--space-xs); }
.m-2 { margin: var(--space-sm); }
.m-3 { margin: var(--space-md); }

/* Color system with automatic variants */
.bg-primary { 
  background-color: hsl(var(--primary));
  color: hsl(from hsl(var(--primary)) h s calc(l - 60%));
}

/* Responsive by default */
.grid {
  display: grid;
  grid-template-columns: repeat(auto-fit, minmax(min(100%, 20rem), 1fr));
  gap: var(--space-md);
}

3. Component System (nexus-components.css)

css
/* Base component with complexity levels */
.nexus-card {
  padding: var(--space-md);
  border-radius: var(--border-radius);
  background: white;
  box-shadow: 
    0 1px 3px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, calc(0.1 * var(--shadow-intensity))),
    0 1px 2px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, calc(0.06 * var(--shadow-intensity)));
  
  @media (--complexity-balanced) {
    border: 1px solid var(--border-color);
  }
  
  @media (--complexity-complex) {
    backdrop-filter: blur(10px);
    background: hsla(0, 0%, 100%, 0.8);
  }
}

4. Design System Adapters (nexus-themes.css)

css
/* Notion-style theme */
[data-theme="notion"] {
  --scale: 1.1;
  --shadow-intensity: 0.05;
  --border-radius: 0.25rem;
  --font-family: ui-sans-serif, -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, sans-serif;
}

/* Heavy/Glassmorphism theme */
[data-theme="glass"] {
  --scale: 1.3;
  --shadow-intensity: 0.3;
  --border-radius: 1rem;
}

Implementation Features

1. Intelligent Grid System

css
.nexus-grid {
  display: grid;
  grid-template-columns: 
    [full-start] minmax(var(--space-md), 1fr) 
    [main-start] min(100% - calc(var(--space-md) * 2), 80ch) [main-end]
    minmax(var(--space-md), 1fr) [full-end];
}

.nexus-grid > * {
  grid-column: main;
}

.nexus-grid > .full {
  grid-column: full;
}

2. Adaptive Components

html

<!-- Complex usage with utilities -->

            backdrop-blur-md border border-white/20 
            shadow-2xl hover:scale-105 transition-all">
  Glass morphism card
</div>

css

  position: relative;
  transition: all 0.1s ease;
}

.nexus-block:hover::before {
  content: '';
  position: absolute;
  left: -1rem;
  top: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  width: 2px;
  background: var(--primary);
}

/* Advanced animation system */
.nexus-stagger > * {
  animation: slideInUp 0.5s ease calc(var(--index) * 0.1s) both;
}

1. Modular Import System

scss

3. Performance Features

  • Automatic CSS Compression: Removes unused utilities

  • Critical CSS Inlining: Detects above-the-fold styles

  • Component Lazy Loading: Loads complex styles only when needed

Thought for 68 seconds

We are building a new CSS framework called "Nexus CSS". We have already outlined a plan that aims to combine the best features of existing frameworks while avoiding their drawbacks.

Now, we are considering incorporating ideas from two specific frameworks: Halfmoon and Pico CSS.

Let's first note down the key features and strengths of Halfmoon and Pico CSS:

Halfmoon CSS:

  • Built-in dark mode (with a toggle) and customizable sidebars and modals.

  • Provides a set of well-designed components and utilities.

  • Has a built-in JS library for interactive components (like dropdowns, modals, etc.).

  • Uses CSS variables for theming.

  • Responsive and mobile-friendly.

Pico CSS:

  • Minimalistic and semantic HTML-first approach.

  • Very lightweight (around 10 KB minified).

  • No build steps, no dependencies, and no classes for basic elements (like buttons, forms, etc.).

  • Uses semantic HTML and attribute-based styling for some components (e.g., <button role="button">).

  • Responsive and with a clean, modern design.

Given our goal for Nexus CSS to be lightweight, easy to learn, and capable of handling both simple and complex projects, we can take inspiration from both:

  1. From Halfmoon:

    • Built-in dark mode and theme switching.

    • Well-designed components with a focus on aesthetics.

    • Use of CSS variables for easy theming.

  2. From Pico:

    • Semantic HTML support for basic elements (so that beginners can just use HTML and get a nice style).

    • Minimalistic and lightweight core.

    • Attribute-based styling for some components (e.g., [role="button"]).

We can integrate these ideas into Nexus CSS by:

  • Having a base layer that styles semantic HTML (like Pico) so that beginners can get started without any classes.

  • Providing a utility class system (like Tailwind) for custom designs.

  • Offering a component class system (like Bootstrap) for pre-built components.

  • Using CSS variables for theming and dark mode (like Halfmoon).

  • Providing an optional JavaScript library for interactive components (like Halfmoon) but keeping the core CSS framework independent of JS.

Let's adjust our plan for Nexus CSS to incorporate these ideas.

Revised Plan for Nexus CSS

Core Layers:

  1. Reset/Normalize + Semantic HTML Styles (like Pico):

    • Style basic HTML elements (headings, paragraphs, buttons, forms, etc.) so that a plain HTML page looks good without any classes.

  2. Design Token Layer (CSS Custom Properties):

    • Define a comprehensive set of variables for colors, spacing, typography, etc.

  3. Utility Classes (like Tailwind):

    • A set of atomic classes for margin, padding, colors, etc.

  4. Component Classes (like Bootstrap):

    • Pre-built components (cards, alerts, modals, etc.) that can be used with class names.

  5. Layout System:

    • A flexbox and grid-based layout system.

  6. Theme and Dark Mode (like Halfmoon):

    • Built-in dark mode and theme switching via CSS variables and a class toggle.

  7. Optional JavaScript:

    • For interactive components (dropdowns, modals, etc.) but keep it optional.

File Structure:

text
nexus.css (base styles + semantic HTML + design tokens) - 5KB
nexus-utilities.css (utility classes) - 5KB
nexus-components.css (component classes) - 10KB
nexus-layout.css (layout system) - 3KB
nexus-js.js (optional JavaScript) - 10KB

Implementation Details:

1. Semantic HTML Styles (like Pico)

We'll style basic HTML elements so that they look good without any classes. For example:

css
/* nexus-base.css */
html {
  font-family: system-ui, sans-serif;
  line-height: 1.5;
}

button, input, select, textarea {
  font-family: inherit;
  font-size: 100%;
  line-height: 1.15;
  margin: 0;
}

  background-color: var(--primary);
  color: white;
  border: none;
  border-radius: var(--border-radius);
}

We'll define a set of CSS variables for theming and dark mode.

css
:root {

  --warning: #ffc107;

  --light: #f8f9fa;

  --primary: #0056b3;
  --background: #1a1a1a;
  --text-color: #ffffff;
  /* ... */

css

We'll create components that are built using the design tokens and utility classes.

css

We'll provide a flexbox and grid-based layout system.

css

We can use a class or data attribute to toggle dark mode.

css

7. Optional JavaScript

We can write a small JavaScript library to handle interactive components.

js
// nexus-js.js
class Nexus {
  static toggleDarkMode() {
    document.documentElement.setAttribute('data-theme', 
      document.documentElement.getAttribute('data-theme') === 'dark' ? 'light' : 'dark'
    );
  }

  // ... other methods for modals, dropdowns, etc.
}

Learning Path:

  • Beginner: Just use semantic HTML and maybe a few component classes.

Enhanced Design Token System

css
:root {
  /* Pico-inspired spacing */
  --space-unit: 1rem;
  --space-xs: calc(var(--space-unit) / 4);
  --space-sm: calc(var(--space-unit) / 2);
  --space-md: var(--space-unit);
  --space-lg: calc(var(--space-unit) * 1.5);
  --space-xl: calc(var(--space-unit) * 2);
  
  /* Halfmoon-inspired color system */
  --primary-h: 220;
  --primary-s: 100%;
  --primary-l: 50%;
  --primary: hsl(var(--primary-h), var(--primary-s), var(--primary-l));
  
  /* Automatic dark mode colors */
  @media (prefers-color-scheme: dark) {
    --bg-primary: hsl(0, 0%, 10%);
    --text-primary: hsl(0, 0%, 90%);
  }
  
  /* Complexity scaling */
  --complexity: simple; /* simple | balanced | rich */
}

Thought for 22 seconds

We are considering the name "Nexus" vs "CRAFTS" (which is an acronym for Clean, Responsive, Accessible, Flexible, Typographic, Semantic). Let's analyze the pros and cons of each and then decide.

Pros and Cons of "Nexus"

Pros:

  1. Short and Memorable: Easy to remember and type.

  2. Modern and Techy: Sounds like a central point connecting different parts, which aligns with the framework's goal of being a bridge between simplicity and complexity.

  3. Brandable: Unique enough to stand out and has a cool factor.

  4. Neutral: Doesn't imply any specific design style, allowing for future evolution.

  5. Global Appeal: Easy to pronounce in many languages.

Cons:

  1. Abstract: Doesn't immediately convey what the framework does.

  2. Existing Usage: There are other projects named Nexus (e.g., Nexus Mods, Sonatype Nexus) which might cause confusion, but in the CSS framework space, it might be unique.

Pros and Cons of "CRAFTS"

Pros:

  1. Descriptive: The acronym clearly communicates key features (Clean, Responsive, Accessible, Flexible, Typographic, Semantic).

  2. Professional: Sounds like a tool for professionals who care about these qualities.

  3. Easy to Remember: The acronym spells a word that is easy to recall.

  4. Sets Expectations: Users immediately know what the framework values.

Cons:

  1. Longer: 6 letters vs 5 for Nexus, but both are short.

  2. Might be Limiting: If the framework evolves beyond these core principles, the name might become restrictive.

  3. Less Brandable: The name is more descriptive and less unique, which might make it harder to stand out.

Final Thought

Both names have their merits. However, I lean towards Nexus for the following reasons:

  • It's more brandable and has a modern feel.

  • It doesn't lock us into a specific set of features (whereas CRAFTS is an acronym that we must live up to exactly).

  • It's shorter and has a nice ring to it.

But note: the name CRAFTS is also good and descriptive. If we want to emphasize the framework's principles upfront, CRAFTS is a strong candidate.

Alternatively, we could combine the two: Nexus Crafts or Crafts Nexus? But that might be too long.

Let me know your preference. We can proceed with either.

However, given that we've been using "Nexus" in our planning so far, and it's a solid name, I suggest sticking with Nexus CSS.

But if you prefer CRAFTS, we can change the name and adjust the class prefixes (e.g., .crafts-btn instead of .nexus-btn).

What do you think?

json

  ],

    "dev": "live-server --watch=src,examples",

}

2.2 Create Basic Build Script

Create build.js:

javascript
const fs = require('fs');
const path = require('path');

// Simple CSS concatenation for now
const coreFiles = [
  'src/core/_variables.css',
  'src/core/_reset.css', 
  'src/core/_semantic.css'
];

let output = '/* CRAFTS CSS v1.0.0 - Built: ' + new Date().toISOString() + ' */\n\n';

coreFiles.forEach(file => {
  if (fs.existsSync(file)) {
    output += `/* ${path.basename(file)} */\n`;
    output += fs.readFileSync(file, 'utf8') + '\n\n';
  }
});

// Ensure dist directory exists
if (!fs.existsSync('dist')) {
  fs.mkdirSync('dist');
}

fs.writeFileSync('dist/crafts-semantic.css', output);
console.log('âœ… Built crafts-semantic.css');

// Create full version (we'll expand this later)
fs.writeFileSync('dist/crafts.css', output);
console.log('âœ… Built crafts.css');

Step 3: Let's Write Our First CSS!

3.1 Create Design Tokens (src/core/_variables.css)

css
/* CRAFTS CSS Design Tokens */
:root {
  /* === Spacing Scale === */
  --crafts-space-unit: 1rem;
  --crafts-space-xs: calc(var(--crafts-space-unit) / 4);
  --crafts-space-sm: calc(var(--crafts-space-unit) / 2);
  --crafts-space-md: var(--crafts-space-unit);
  --crafts-space-lg: calc(var(--crafts-space-unit) * 1.5);
  --crafts-space-xl: calc(var(--crafts-space-unit) * 2);
  --crafts-space-2xl: calc(var(--crafts-space-unit) * 3);
  
  /* === Color System === */
  /* Primary Colors */
  --crafts-primary-h: 220;
  --crafts-primary-s: 100%;
  --crafts-primary-l: 50%;
  --crafts-primary: hsl(
    var(--crafts-primary-h), 
    var(--crafts-primary-s), 
    var(--crafts-primary-l)
  );
  
  /* Neutral Colors */
  --crafts-white: hsl(0, 0%, 100%);
  --crafts-gray-50: hsl(0, 0%, 98%);
  --crafts-gray-100: hsl(0, 0%, 96%);
  --crafts-gray-200: hsl(0, 0%, 90%);
  --crafts-gray-300: hsl(0, 0%, 80%);
  --crafts-gray-400: hsl(0, 0%, 60%);
  --crafts-gray-500: hsl(0, 0%, 50%);
  --crafts-gray-600: hsl(0, 0%, 40%);
  --crafts-gray-700: hsl(0, 0%, 30%);
  --crafts-gray-800: hsl(0, 0%, 20%);
  --crafts-gray-900: hsl(0, 0%, 10%);
  --crafts-black: hsl(0, 0%, 0%);
  
  /* Semantic Colors */
  --crafts-bg-primary: var(--crafts-white);
  --crafts-bg-secondary: var(--crafts-gray-50);
  --crafts-text-primary: var(--crafts-gray-900);
  --crafts-text-secondary: var(--crafts-gray-600);
  --crafts-border-color: var(--crafts-gray-200);
  
  /* === Typography === */
  --crafts-font-family: system-ui, -apple-system, "Segoe UI", Roboto, sans-serif;
  --crafts-font-mono: "SFMono-Regular", "Consolas", "Liberation Mono", monospace;
  --crafts-line-height: 1.6;
  --crafts-font-scale: 1.2;
  
  --crafts-text-xs: 0.75rem;
  --crafts-text-sm: 0.875rem;
  --crafts-text-base: 1rem;
  --crafts-text-lg: 1.125rem;
  --crafts-text-xl: 1.25rem;
  --crafts-text-2xl: 1.5rem;
  --crafts-text-3xl: 1.875rem;
  
  /* === Border Radius === */
  --crafts-radius-sm: 0.25rem;
  --crafts-radius-md: 0.375rem;
  --crafts-radius-lg: 0.5rem;
  --crafts-radius-xl: 0.75rem;
  
  /* === Shadows === */
  --crafts-shadow-sm: 0 1px 2px 0 rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.05);
  --crafts-shadow-md: 0 4px 6px -1px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1);
  --crafts-shadow-lg: 0 10px 15px -3px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1);
  
  /* === Complexity Levels === */
  --crafts-complexity: simple; /* simple | balanced | complex */
}

/* Dark Mode Variables */
@media (prefers-color-scheme: dark) {
  :root {
    --crafts-bg-primary: var(--crafts-gray-900);
    --crafts-bg-secondary: var(--crafts-gray-800);
    --crafts-text-primary: var(--crafts-gray-100);
    --crafts-text-secondary: var(--crafts-gray-300);
    --crafts-border-color: var(--crafts-gray-700);
  }
}

/* High Contrast Mode Support */
@media (prefers-contrast: high) {
  :root {
    --crafts-border-color: var(--crafts-black);
  }
}

3.2 Create Smart Reset (src/core/_reset.css)

css
/* CRAFTS CSS Smart Reset */
/* Modern reset that preserves semantic meaning */

/* Box sizing reset */
*, *::before, *::after {
  box-sizing: border-box;
}

/* Remove default margin and padding */
* {
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
}

/* HTML focus outline preservation */
html:focus-within {
  scroll-behavior: smooth;
}

/* Body defaults */
body {
  min-height: 100vh;
  text-rendering: optimizeSpeed;
  line-height: var(--crafts-line-height);
  font-family: var(--crafts-font-family);
  background-color: var(--crafts-bg-primary);
  color: var(--crafts-text-primary);
}

/* Remove list styles on ul, ol elements */
ul, ol {
  list-style: none;
}

/* Anchor elements */
a {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}

/* Button reset */
button {
  background: none;
  border: none;
  font: inherit;
  cursor: pointer;
}

/* Form element reset */
input, textarea, select {
  font: inherit;
  border: none;
  background: none;
}

/* Media defaults */
img, picture, video, canvas, svg {
  display: block;
  max-width: 100%;
  height: auto;
}

/* Avoid text overflows */
p, h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 {
  overflow-wrap: break-word;
}

/* Reduce motion for accessibility */
@media (prefers-reduced-motion: reduce) {
  html:focus-within {
    scroll-behavior: auto;
  }
  
  *, *::before, *::after {
    animation-duration: 0.01ms !important;
    animation-iteration-count: 1 !important;
    transition-duration: 0.01ms !important;
    scroll-behavior: auto !important;
  }
}

Let's Fix This Step by Step

Step 1: Update the Semantic CSS (src/core/_semantic.css)

Replace the content with this enhanced version:

css
/* CRAFTS CSS Semantic Elements */
/* Beautiful, accessible styling for native HTML elements */

/* ===== TYPOGRAPHY ===== */
h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 {
  font-weight: 600;
  line-height: 1.3;
  margin-bottom: var(--crafts-space-md);
  color: var(--crafts-text-primary);
}

h1 {
  font-size: var(--crafts-text-3xl);
  margin-top: var(--crafts-space-xl);
}

h2 {
  font-size: var(--crafts-text-2xl);
  margin-top: var(--crafts-space-lg);
}

h3 {
  font-size: var(--crafts-text-xl);
  margin-top: var(--crafts-space-lg);
}

p {
  margin-bottom: var(--crafts-space-md);
  color: var(--crafts-text-primary);
  max-width: 65ch; /* Optimal reading length */
}

/* ===== LISTS ===== */
ul, ol {
  margin-bottom: var(--crafts-space-md);
  padding-left: var(--crafts-space-lg);
}

ul {
  list-style-type: disc;
}

ol {
  list-style-type: decimal;
}

li {
  margin-bottom: var(--crafts-space-xs);
  color: var(--crafts-text-primary);
}

/* ===== FORM ELEMENTS ===== */
label {
  display: block;
  margin-bottom: var(--crafts-space-xs);
  font-weight: 500;
  color: var(--crafts-text-primary);
}

input, textarea, select {
  width: 100%;
  padding: var(--crafts-space-sm) var(--crafts-space-md);
  border: 1px solid var(--crafts-border-color);
  border-radius: var(--crafts-radius-md);
  background-color: var(--crafts-bg-primary);
  color: var(--crafts-text-primary);
  font-size: var(--crafts-text-base);
  margin-bottom: var(--crafts-space-md);
  transition: all 0.2s ease;
}

input:focus, textarea:focus, select:focus {
  outline: none;
  border-color: var(--crafts-primary);
  box-shadow: 0 0 0 3px color-mix(in srgb, var(--crafts-primary) 25%, transparent);
}

/* ===== BUTTONS ===== */
button, 
input[type="submit"], 
input[type="button"] {
  display: inline-block;
  padding: var(--crafts-space-sm) var(--crafts-space-lg);
  background-color: var(--crafts-primary);

Before we proceed next, I have something to know: 1. Which line, or material or other type minimal icons should we use for nice minimal look like dev.to, medium, or notion 2. What will be our basic fonts set which look beautiful anyway on any websites or app?
Thought for 43 seconds

We are building a minimal and elegant CSS framework. Let's address the two points:

  1. Icons: We want minimal, clean icons. Two popular choices are:

    • Feather Icons (https://feathericons.com/) - very minimal, consistent, and open source.

    • Lucide Icons (https://lucide.dev/) - a community-run fork of Feather Icons, also minimal and well-maintained.

    Since we are aiming for a minimal look like dev.to, Medium, or Notion, both are excellent. I would suggest including Feather Icons or Lucide by default in the framework? Or should we leave icons to the user?

    However, note that including icons in a CSS framework is not common. Typically, icons are added separately. But we can provide a way to use icons easily. Alternatively, we can use a CDN for icons in our examples and documentation.

    Let me check: dev.to uses Font Awesome, Medium uses custom icons, and Notion uses a mix of custom and Feather-like icons.

    Since we are going for minimalism, I suggest we don't bundle icons but recommend Feather Icons or Lucide in the documentation. We can provide a helper class for icon sizing and alignment if needed.

  2. Fonts: We want a beautiful font stack that works on any website. The trend is towards system fonts for performance and native look. However, we can also provide an option for web fonts.

    A good system font stack (like what Medium uses) is:

    text
    -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, "Segoe UI", Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, "Open Sans", "Helvetica Neue", sans-serif

    For monospace:

    text
    "SFMono-Regular", Consolas, "Liberation Mono", Menlo, Courier, monospace

    Alternatively, we can use the same font stack as Tailwind CSS:

    text
    font-family: ui-sans-serif, system-ui, -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, "Segoe UI", Roboto, "Helvetica Neue", Arial, "Noto Sans", sans-serif, "Apple Color Emoji", "Segoe UI Emoji", "Segoe UI Symbol", "Noto Color Emoji";

    And for monospace:

    text
    font-family: ui-monospace, SFMono-Regular, Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Liberation Mono", "Courier New", monospace;

    We can define these as CSS variables so users can override them.

    We might also want to include an option for a popular web font like Inter (which is used by many modern websites). But note that including web fonts would increase the size and require hosting or a CDN.

    Since we are focusing on minimalism and performance, let's stick with system fonts by default, but provide a way to use Inter if the user wants.

    We can do:

    css
    :root {
  --crafts-font-family: system-ui, -apple-system, "Segoe UI", Roboto, sans-serif;
  --crafts-font-mono: ui-monospace, SFMono-Regular, Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, monospace;
}

    And then in the documentation, we can show how to use Inter.

    Alternatively, we can have two versions: one with system fonts and one with Inter? But that might be overkill.

    Let's keep it simple: system fonts by default, and if the user wants to use Inter, they can override the font family variable.

    We can also provide a class to use Inter, but that would require including the font. We don't want to force the font on everyone.

    So, plan:

    • Use system fonts by default.

    • In the documentation, show how to use Inter (or other fonts) by overriding the variable and including the font from Google Fonts.

    Example for Inter:

    html
    <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Inter:wght@400;500;600;700&display=swap" rel="stylesheet">

    Then in CSS:

    css
    :root {
  --crafts-font-family: 'Inter', system-ui, sans-serif;
}

    We can also consider including a crafts-with-inter.css that does this, but again, it's extra. Let's wait for user demand.

    So, for now, we'll set the system font stack.

Let's update our _variables.css with the font stacks.

We'll use:

css
--crafts-font-family: system-ui, -apple-system, "Segoe UI", Roboto, "Helvetica Neue", Arial, "Noto Sans", sans-serif, "Apple Color Emoji", "Segoe UI Emoji", "Segoe UI Symbol", "Noto Color Emoji";
--crafts-font-mono: ui-monospace, SFMono-Regular, Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, "Liberation Mono", "Courier New", monospace;

This is similar to Tailwind's default and covers a lot of bases.

Now, let's update the _variables.css and _semantic.css to use these variables.

We already have the variables in _variables.css and we are using them in _semantic.css for the body and code elements.

We are on the right track.

Step 4: Update the Build Script

Update build.js to include the new icons file:

javascript
const fs = require('fs');
const path = require('path');

// Core files (semantic version)
const coreFiles = [
  'src/core/_variables.css',
  'src/core/_reset.css', 
  'src/core/_semantic.css'
];

// Full framework files
const fullFiles = [
  ...coreFiles,
  'src/components/_icons.css',
  'src/components/_components.css',
  'src/components/_forms.css',
  'src/layout/_grid.css',
  'src/layout/_layout.css',
  'src/utilities/_utils.css',
  'src/utilities/_themes.css'
];

function buildCSS(files, outputPath) {
  let output = '/* CRAFTS CSS v1.0.0 - Built: ' + new Date().toISOString() + ' */\n\n';
  
  files.forEach(file => {
    if (fs.existsSync(file)) {
      output += `/* ${path.basename(file)} */\n`;
      output += fs.readFileSync(file, 'utf8') + '\n\n';
    } else {
      console.log(`âš ï¸  Missing: ${file}`);
    }
  });

  // Ensure dist directory exists
  if (!fs.existsSync('dist')) {
    fs.mkdirSync('dist');
  }

  fs.writeFileSync(outputPath, output);
  console.log(`âœ… Built ${outputPath}`);
}

// Build semantic version (core only)
buildCSS(coreFiles, 'dist/crafts-semantic.css');

// Build full version
buildCSS(fullFiles, 'dist/crafts.css');

console.log('ðŸŽ‰ Build complete!');
console.log('ðŸ“ dist/crafts-semantic.css - Core semantic styles');
console.log('ðŸ“ dist/crafts.css - Full framework');

/* 
 * CRAFTS Theme Switcher Component

  display: inline-flex;
  gap: var(--crafts-space-xs);
  padding: var(--crafts-space-xs);

  height: 2rem;

  transition: all 0.2s ease;
}

}

  background: var(--crafts-primary);
  color: white;
}

Step 4: Update Build Script

Update build.js to include new components:

javascript
const fs = require('fs');
const path = require('path');

/*
 * CRAFTS CSS Build Script
 * Concatenates all CSS files in the correct order
 * Creates both semantic and full framework versions
 */

// Core files (semantic version - minimal)
const coreFiles = [
  'src/core/_variables.css',
  'src/core/_reset.css', 
  'src/core/_semantic.css'
];

// Full framework files (complete build)
const fullFiles = [
  ...coreFiles,
  'src/components/_icons.css',
  'src/components/_theme-switcher.css',
  'src/components/_navbar.css',
  'src/components/_footer.css',
  'src/components/_components.css',
  'src/components/_forms.css',
  'src/layout/_grid.css',
  'src/layout/_layout.css',
  'src/utilities/_utils.css',
  'src/utilities/_themes.css'
];

function buildCSS(files, outputPath) {
  let output = `/*! CRAFTS CSS v1.0.0 - ${new Date().toISOString().split('T')[0]} */\n`;
  output += '/*! https://github.com/TechnoVen/crafts */\n\n';
  
  files.forEach(file => {
    if (fs.existsSync(file)) {
      output += `\n/* === ${path.basename(file)} === */\n\n`;
      output += fs.readFileSync(file, 'utf8') + '\n';
    } else {
      console.log(`âš ï¸  Missing: ${file}`);
    }
  });

  // Ensure dist directory exists
  if (!fs.existsSync('dist')) {
    fs.mkdirSync('dist');
  }

  fs.writeFileSync(outputPath, output);
  console.log(`âœ… Built ${outputPath}`);
}

// Build semantic version (core only)
buildCSS(coreFiles, 'dist/crafts-semantic.css');

// Build full version
buildCSS(fullFiles, 'dist/crafts.css');

console.log('ðŸŽ‰ Build complete!');
console.log('ðŸ“ dist/crafts-semantic.css - Core semantic styles (2KB)');
console.log('ðŸ“ dist/crafts.css - Full framework (15KB)');

        // Initialize Lucide icons

        // Theme switcher functionality
        document.querySelectorAll('.crafts-theme-btn').forEach(btn => {
            btn.addEventListener('click', () => {
                const theme = btn.getAttribute('data-theme');
                
                // Update active state
                document.querySelectorAll('.crafts-theme-btn').forEach(b => b.classList.remove('active'));
                btn.classList.add('active');
                
                // Set theme
                document.documentElement.setAttribute('data-theme', theme);
                
                // Store preference
                localStorage.setItem('crafts-theme', theme);
            });
        });

        // Load saved theme
        const savedTheme = localStorage.getItem('crafts-theme') || 'auto';
        document.documentElement.setAttribute('data-theme', savedTheme);
        document.querySelector(`[data-theme="${savedTheme}"]`)?.classList.add('active');

        // Mobile menu toggle
        document.getElementById('mobileToggle')?.addEventListener('click', () => {
            document.querySelector('.crafts-navbar-nav').classList.toggle('show');
        });
    </script>

                document.documentElement.setAttribute('data-theme', theme);
                
                // Store preference
                localStorage.setItem('crafts-theme', theme);
            });

        const savedTheme = localStorage.getItem('crafts-theme') || 'auto';
        document.documentElement.setAttribute('data-theme', savedTheme);
        document.querySelector(`[data-theme="${savedTheme}"]`)?.classList.add('active');

Step 5: Update Build Script

Update build.js to include new components:

javascript
const fs = require('fs');
const path = require('path');

/*
 * CRAFTS CSS Build Script
 * Concatenates all CSS files in the correct order
 * Creates both semantic and full framework versions
 */

// Core files (semantic version - minimal)
const coreFiles = [
  'src/core/_variables.css',
  'src/core/_reset.css', 
  'src/core/_semantic.css'
];

// Full framework files (complete build)
const fullFiles = [
  ...coreFiles,
  'src/components/_icons.css',
  'src/components/_theme-switcher.css',
  'src/components/_navbar.css',
  'src/components/_cards.css',
  'src/components/_forms.css',
  'src/components/_footer.css',
  'src/layout/_grid.css',
  'src/layout/_layout.css',
  'src/utilities/_utils.css',
  'src/utilities/_themes.css'
];

function buildCSS(files, outputPath) {
  let output = `/*! CRAFTS CSS v1.0.0 - ${new Date().toISOString().split('T')[0]} */\n`;
  output += '/*! https://github.com/TechnoVen/crafts */\n\n';
  
  files.forEach(file => {
    if (fs.existsSync(file)) {
      output += `\n/* === ${path.basename(file)} === */\n\n`;
      output += fs.readFileSync(file, 'utf8') + '\n';
    } else {
      console.log(`âš ï¸  Missing: ${file}`);
    }
  });

  // Ensure dist directory exists
  if (!fs.existsSync('dist')) {
    fs.mkdirSync('dist');
  }

  fs.writeFileSync(outputPath, output);
  console.log(`âœ… Built ${outputPath}`);
}

// Build semantic version (core only)
buildCSS(coreFiles, 'dist/crafts-semantic.css');

// Build full version
buildCSS(fullFiles, 'dist/crafts.css');

console.log('ðŸŽ‰ Build complete!');
console.log('ðŸ“ dist/crafts-semantic.css - Core semantic styles');
console.log('ðŸ“ dist/crafts.css - Full framework with components');

    <script>
        // Initialize Lucide icons
        lucide.createIcons();

        // Theme switcher functionality
        document.querySelectorAll('.crafts-theme-btn').forEach(btn => {
            btn.addEventListener('click', () => {
                const theme = btn.getAttribute('data-theme');
                
                // Update active state
                document.querySelectorAll('.crafts-theme-btn').forEach(b => b.classList.remove('active'));
                btn.classList.add('active');
                
                // Set theme
                document.documentElement.setAttribute('data-theme', theme);
                
                // Store preference
                localStorage.setItem('crafts-theme', theme);
            });
        });

        // Load saved theme
        const savedTheme = localStorage.getItem('crafts-theme') || 'auto';
        document.documentElement.setAttribute('data-theme', savedTheme);
        document.querySelector(`[data-theme="${savedTheme}"]`)?.classList.add('active');

        // Mobile menu toggle
        document.getElementById('navToggle')?.addEventListener('click', () => {
            document.querySelector('.crafts-nav-links').classList.toggle('show');
        });
    </script>

Thought for 159 seconds

We are seeing two main issues:

  1. The page is edge-to-edge, which means our container class is not being applied correctly or we need to adjust the layout.

  2. The theme switcher is not aesthetically pleasing and should be a dropdown or a toggle switch.

Let's address these:

For the container issue, we have a class .crafts-container that sets a max-width and centers the content. We need to make sure that we are using this class in the right places.

For the theme switcher, let's change it to a more compact and visually appealing dropdown. We can use a select dropdown or a custom dropdown with icons. However, the requirement is to have a toggle switch or dropdown. Since we have three options (light, dark, auto), a dropdown might be better.

Alternatively, we can use a toggle switch that cycles between the three states, but that might be less intuitive. Let's go for a dropdown.

We'll create a new component for a theme dropdown.

Steps:

  1. Create a new component for the theme dropdown.

  2. Replace the current theme switcher with the dropdown.

  3. Adjust the container usage to ensure the content is not edge-to-edge.

Step 3: Update the JavaScript.

We need to:

  • Toggle the dropdown menu when the toggle button is clicked.

  • Close the dropdown when clicking outside.

  • Update the current theme and the dropdown display when a theme is selected.

We'll adjust the JavaScript:

// Theme dropdown functionality
const themeDropdownToggle = document.querySelector('.crafts-theme-dropdown-toggle');
const themeDropdownMenu = document.querySelector('.crafts-theme-dropdown-menu');
const themeCurrent = document.querySelector('.crafts-theme-current');
const themeDropdownItems = document.querySelectorAll('.crafts-theme-dropdown-item');

// Toggle dropdown
themeDropdownToggle.addEventListener('click', () => {
themeDropdownMenu.classList.toggle('show');
});

// Close dropdown when clicking outside
document.addEventListener('click', (event) => {
if (!event.target.closest('.crafts-theme-dropdown')) {
themeDropdownMenu.classList.remove('show');
}
});

// Handle theme selection
themeDropdownItems.forEach(item => {
item.addEventListener('click', () => {
const theme = item.getAttribute('data-theme');

text
   // Update active state
   themeDropdownItems.forEach(i => i.classList.remove('active'));
   item.classList.add('active');
   
   // Update current theme display
   const icon = item.querySelector('i').cloneNode(true);
   const text = item.textContent.trim();
   themeCurrent.innerHTML = '';
   themeCurrent.appendChild(icon);
   themeCurrent.appendChild(document.createTextNode(text));
   
   // Set theme
   document.documentElement.setAttribute('data-theme', theme);
   
   // Store preference
   localStorage.setItem('crafts-theme', theme);
   
   // Close dropdown
   themeDropdownMenu.classList.remove('show');
 });

});

// Load saved theme
const savedTheme = localStorage.getItem('crafts-theme') || 'auto';
document.documentElement.setAttribute('data-theme', savedTheme);
// Find the corresponding dropdown item and set it as active
const savedThemeItem = document.querySelector(.crafts-theme-dropdown-item[data-theme="${savedTheme}"]);
if (savedThemeItem) {
savedThemeItem.classList.add('active');
// Update current theme display
const icon = savedThemeItem.querySelector('i').cloneNode(true);
const text = savedThemeItem.textContent.trim();
themeCurrent.innerHTML = '';
themeCurrent.appendChild(icon);
themeCurrent.appendChild(document.createTextNode(text));
}

Step 4: Update Build Script

Update build.js to include new components:

javascript
const fs = require('fs');
const path = require('path');

/*
 * CRAFTS CSS Build Script
 * Concatenates all CSS files in the correct order
 * Creates both semantic and full framework versions
 */

// Core files (semantic version - minimal)
const coreFiles = [
  'src/core/_variables.css',
  'src/core/_reset.css', 
  'src/core/_semantic.css'
];

// Full framework files (complete build)
const fullFiles = [
  ...coreFiles,
  'src/components/_icons.css',
  'src/components/_theme-toggle.css',
  'src/components/_buttons.css',
  'src/components/_navbar.css',
  'src/components/_cards.css',
  'src/components/_forms.css',
  'src/components/_footer.css',
  'src/layout/_grid.css',
  'src/layout/_layout.css',
  'src/utilities/_utils.css',
  'src/utilities/_themes.css'
];

function buildCSS(files, outputPath) {
  let output = `/*! CRAFTS CSS v1.0.0 - ${new Date().toISOString().split('T')[0]} */\n`;
  output += '/*! https://github.com/TechnoVen/crafts */\n\n';
  
  files.forEach(file => {
    if (fs.existsSync(file)) {
      output += `\n/* === ${path.basename(file)} === */\n\n`;
      output += fs.readFileSync(file, 'utf8') + '\n';
    } else {
      console.log(`âš ï¸  Missing: ${file}`);
    }
  });

  // Ensure dist directory exists
  if (!fs.existsSync('dist')) {
    fs.mkdirSync('dist');
  }

  fs.writeFileSync(outputPath, output);
  console.log(`âœ… Built ${outputPath}`);
}

// Build semantic version (core only)
buildCSS(coreFiles, 'dist/crafts-semantic.css');

// Build full version
buildCSS(fullFiles, 'dist/crafts.css');

console.log('ðŸŽ‰ Build complete!');
console.log('ðŸ“ dist/crafts-semantic.css - Core semantic styles');
console.log('ðŸ“ dist/crafts.css - Full framework with components');

    <script>
        // Initialize Lucide icons
        lucide.createIcons();

        // Theme toggle functionality
        const themeToggle = document.getElementById('themeToggle');
        const prefersDark = window.matchMedia('(prefers-color-scheme: dark)').matches;
        
        // Set initial state based on saved preference or system preference
        const savedTheme = localStorage.getItem('crafts-theme');
        if (savedTheme === 'dark' || (!savedTheme && prefersDark)) {
            document.documentElement.setAttribute('data-theme', 'dark');
            themeToggle.checked = true;
        } else {
            document.documentElement.setAttribute('data-theme', 'light');
            themeToggle.checked = false;
        }

        // Toggle theme
        themeToggle.addEventListener('change', () => {
            const isDark = themeToggle.checked;
            document.documentElement.setAttribute('data-theme', isDark ? 'dark' : 'light');
            localStorage.setItem('crafts-theme', isDark ? 'dark' : 'light');
        });

        // Mobile menu toggle
        document.getElementById('navToggle')?.addEventListener('click', () => {
            document.querySelector('.crafts-nav-links').classList.toggle('show');
        });
    </script>
</body>
</html>

Hi you are doing good! But still some issues are there and you missed to fix them. Take a deep breath. Let's understand the problem: the page is not well defined so follow this example below, we need a default size later the user and developer can defined their owns. Any case keep our Framework principal and ideas intact. HTML Container Edge Full To ensure a container does not extend to the edge of the page and instead maintains internal spacing, you need to address default browser styling and positioning. First, reset the default margin and padding on the `body` and `html` elements to eliminate any inherited spacing: ```css body, html { margin: 0; padding: 0; } ``` This ensures the container's width is not affected by default browser padding or margins Next, apply `box-sizing: border-box` to include borders and padding within the element's defined width, preventing unintended expansion For a centered container with consistent internal spacing, use a fixed width or a percentage-based width with appropriate padding: ```css .container { width: 100%; max-width: 1200px; /* or any desired maximum width */ margin: 0 auto; padding: 0 2rem; /* internal horizontal padding */ box-sizing: border-box; } ``` This approach keeps the container from touching the page edges while maintaining responsive design. If the container is inside a parent with a fixed width, ensure the parent's `box-sizing` is also set to `border-box` to avoid layout issues Using `padding` on the container itself is the most straightforward method to create internal spacing without affecting the overall layout

You're absolutely right! I missed the fundamental container issue. Let me fix this properly by ensuring our framework has proper container defaults that prevent edge-to-edge content while maintaining our design principles.

Step 1: Fix the Core Reset and Container System

Update src/core/_reset.css

css
/* 
 * CRAFTS CSS Smart Reset
 * Modern reset that preserves semantic meaning while ensuring proper container behavior
 */

/* Box sizing reset with inheritance */
*, *::before, *::after {
  box-sizing: border-box;
}

/* Remove default margin and padding from all elements */
* {
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
}

/* HTML and body reset to ensure no edge-to-edge issues */
html, body {
  margin: 0;
  padding: 0;
  width: 100%;
}

/* Body defaults with proper container behavior */
body {
  min-height: 100vh;
  text-rendering: optimizeSpeed;
  line-height: var(--crafts-line-height);
  font-family: var(--crafts-font-family);
  background-color: var(--crafts-bg-primary);
  color: var(--crafts-text-primary);
  /* Ensure body acts as proper container */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
}

/* HTML focus outline preservation */
html:focus-within {
  scroll-behavior: smooth;
}

/* Remove list styles on ul, ol elements */
ul, ol {
  list-style: none;
}

/* Anchor elements */
a {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}

/* Button reset */
button {
  background: none;
  border: none;
  font: inherit;
  cursor: pointer;
}

/* Form element reset */
input, textarea, select {
  font: inherit;
  border: none;
  background: none;
}

/* Media defaults */
img, picture, video, canvas, svg {
  display: block;
  max-width: 100%;
  height: auto;
}

/* Avoid text overflows */
p, h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 {
  overflow-wrap: break-word;
}

/* Reduce motion for accessibility */
@media (prefers-reduced-motion: reduce) {
  html:focus-within {
    scroll-behavior: auto;
  }
  
  *, *::before, *::after {
    animation-duration: 0.01ms !important;
    animation-iteration-count: 1 !important;
    transition-duration: 0.01ms !important;
    scroll-behavior: auto !important;
  }
}
